pr_title: Improved string conversion framework + object-oriented function call syntax

timeline.message:
Name all string conversion functions to_string().

A slightly more usable string conversion framework.

Background: Automatic string conversion is used in conjunction with
string interpolation to automatically convert DDlog expressions to
strings, e.g. "x=${x}".  For non-builtin types, this requires calling a
user-provided function for the given type.  Since DDlog does not have
traits or type classes, we rely on a predefined naming scheme to locate
this function.  Previously function name was obtained by appending
"2string" to the name of the type.

Now that we support function overloading, we can allow all these
functions to use the same name, `to_string`.  This is far less confusing
and ugly.  There are some limitations:

- The conversion function must reside in the same module as the type it
  applies to.  This is because string conversion is injected after
  flattening; hence we need to know the fully qualified name of the
  function we are searching for.  However, this actually makes sense
  from the usability perspective.

- Conversion functions can only be provided for structs and extern
  types, but not tuples or type aliases.

+Built-in types (`bool`, `bit<>`, `signed<>`, `bigint`, `string`, `float`, `double`)
+have built-in conversions to strings.  To enable the compiler to automatically convert
+a user-defined type to a string, the user must implement a
+function named `to_string` that takes an instance of the type and returns a `string`
+(functions are described [below](#functions)):
+
+```
+funtion to_string(x: Category): string {
+    match (x) {
+        CategoryStarWars -> "Star Wars",
+        CategoryOther -> "other"
+    }
+}
+```

timeline.message:
Use "::" as namespace separator.

We would like to support object-oriented function call syntax `x.f(y)`,
which simply gets converted to `f(x,y)`.  In fact the parser already
supports this; however this feature was broken back when we introduced
the module system, and along with it syntax ambiguity: the parser cannot
distinguish method call from namespace separator.

We eliminate the ambiguity by using `::` as a namespace separator in:

- import clauses, e.g., `import m1::m2`.
- expressions, e.g., `m::func(x)`.
- command language, e.g., `dump uuid_test::UUID`.
Tests for object-oriented function call syntax.
